  I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
the  Republic  of  Uzbekistan for  the  Sustainable  Hydropower  Project. The report  also  describes 
proposed technical assistance (TA) for Enhancing Climate Resilience of Hydropower Plants,1 and 
if the  Board  approves  the  proposed  loan,  I,  acting  under  the  authority  delegated to me  by  the 
Board, approve the TA. 
 
The  proposed  project  will  support  Uzbekistan’s  national  goals  to  increase  renewable 
2. 
energy generation and diversify its energy mix. The project has multifaceted interventions to help 
Uzbekistan (i) deploy small and mini hydropower plants (HPPs) to add 25 megawatts (MW) of 
renewable energy capacity; (ii) develop a hydropower master plan to optimize a future investment 
program,  which  will  help  develop  planning  capacity  for  climate  resilience  and  environmental 
sustainability; and (iii) complement sector reforms by strengthening the institutional capacity of 
Joint-Stock Company Uzbekhydroenergo. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
Benefiting  from  high  commodity  prices,  Uzbekistan  enjoyed  high  economic  growth  that 
3. 
averaged at a rate of 8.4% over the past 10 years. However, the weakening external environment, 
extensive state control, weak governance, and low foreign investments have increasingly slowed 
economic  growth,  necessitating  far-reaching  reforms,  including  continuing  the  institutional  and 
structural reforms of state-owned enterprises (SOEs). The energy sector, which has underpinned 
Uzbekistan’s  sustained  growth  and  contributes  about  20%  to  gross  domestic  product,  faces 
challenges in introducing market-oriented principles to catalyze private sector investment and in 
diversifying  energy  resources  while  scaling  up  urgent  investments  in  critical  infrastructure  to 
support fast-growing power demand and ensure long-term sustainability. 
 
4. 
Uzbekistan has served as an electricity trade hub in Central Asia, where an interconnected 
and  coordinated  power  system  established  during  the  Soviet  era  provided  countries  with  high 
energy security and an optimal energy mix by unifying the region’s unevenly distributed energy 
resources.  Under  this  system,  hydropower-rich  Kyrgyz  Republic  and  Tajikistan  exchanged 
electricity  with  fossil  fuel-generating  Kazakhstan,  Turkmenistan,  and  Uzbekistan.  However,  a 
breakdown  in  this  regionally  coordinated  energy  system  pushed  Uzbekistan  to  rely  heavily  on 
fossil fuels in its generation mix. 
 
5. 
Natural gas is the dominant fossil energy source in the country’s power generation mix, 
contributing 80% of the 63 terawatt-hours of total electricity produced in 2018. Of the 11 gigawatts 
(GW) of thermal power plant capacity in Uzbekistan, more than 40% are 30–40-year-old plants 
with  low  thermal  efficiency.  Most  thermal  power  plants  were  also  designed  for  baseload 
generation with no flexible load management measures, further reducing thermal efficiency and 
power  supply  reliability.  Moreover,  continued  reliance  on  meeting  power  demand  growth  by 
burning fossil fuels, the country’s greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions will rise, as 85% of emissions 
come from the energy sector. 
 

                                                
1  Of which (i) $1,000,000 will be provided by the Climate Change Fund and (ii) $500,000 will be provided by the Clean 
Energy Fund under the Clean Energy Financing Partnership  Facility and administered by the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB). 

 

 

 As part of the complex reform measures undertaken by the government, focus has shifted 
6. 
toward  the  use  of  renewable  energy  to  diversify  energy  sources.  Uzbekistan  has  abundant 
renewable energy resources, and the most harnessed is hydropower, with installed capacity of 
1.9 GW or about 13% of total installed generating capacity. However, this is only about 20% of 
the  country’s  hydropower  potential  of  7.5  GW.2  The  exploitation  of  water  resources  prioritized 
agriculture (i.e., for irrigation purposes) as there were no strategies for integrated water–energy 
resources management through  hydropower  development. Issues  such  as  low  electricity  tariff, 
geological and hydrological risks, and socio-environmental footprints were additional constraints 
to the effective development of hydropower in Uzbekistan. 
 
7. 
In  this  light,  the  government  adopted  a  $2.6  billion  investment  program  to  increase 
hydropower capacity by 1.6 GW by 2030.3 Uzbekhydroenergo was established in May 2017 to 
administer  the  ambitious  program,  backed  by  preferential  tariff  for  hydropower  projects. 
Uzbekhydroenergo  was  created  by  unbundling  the  HPPs  from  Uzbekenergo,  the  vertically 
integrated state utility, and integrating them with HPPs under the Ministry of Agriculture and Water 
Resources.  Hydropower  planning  and  water  resources  management  were  streamlined  into 
Uzbekhydroenergo. 
 
8. 
The  government  requested  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  support  to  align 
hydropower development with the overarching goals of the country’s energy sector development 
and support SOE reform. As a newly established company and a new executing agency for ADB 
projects, Uzbekhydroenergo needs to build management, planning, and technical capacity. ADB 
will  help  improve  Uzbekhydroenergo’s  technical  capability  and  financial  management  skills. 
Initially,  Uzbekhydroenergo  will  focus  on  less  risky  small  hydropower  projects  and  HPP 
rehabilitation. Gradually, it will shift to the development of more complex large HPPs and cross-
border hydropower projects. 
 
9. 
Under  the  project,  Uzbekhydroenergo  will  install  three  small  HPPs  with  24  megawatts 
(MW) total capacity on the Aksu River in Kashkadarya Province; and at least three mini HPPs 
with 1 MW total capacity in rural areas. The government originally proposed 30 MW total capacity 
with dams of 40 to 70 meters in height and storage reservoirs, but Uzbekhydroenergo agreed to 
modify the project design to maintain water flow for the river eco-system and people’s daily use 
in  consideration  of  ADB’s  safeguard  requirements,  international  standards  and  practices,  and, 
more importantly, long-term socio-environmental sustainability. Such joint efforts have helped the 
government  and  Uzbekhydroenergo  infuse  environmental  sustainability  in  the  country’s 
hydropower planning landscape. 
 
10. 
Lessons. ADB has applied lessons from its long-term sector operations in designing the 
project.4 First, development partner coordination meetings and interagency coordination meetings 
help  streamline  government  regulatory  procedures  and  tackle  bureaucratic  hurdles  that  delay 
implementation.  Second,  TA  is  needed  to  strengthen  the  executing  agency’s  planning  and 
implementation capacity and address operational bottlenecks. Third, ADB’s continued support for 
sector and SOE reforms improves project efficiency and overall sector sustainability. In particular, 
ADB  support for  cost recovery  tariff  reforms  will  help  improve  the  sector’s financial  health  and

public services and job opportunities.

12. 
Value added by ADB assistance. ADB, as the largest development partner in Uzbekistan 
energy  sector,  has  provided  direct  support  in  the  design  and  implementation  of  energy  sector 
reforms,  including  unbundling  of  Uzbekenergo  and  tariff  reforms,  and  will  continue  to  mobilize 
support to improve the sector’s sustainability and effectiveness. 6 In line with ongoing efforts, the 
project will leverage SOE reform by strengthening the institutional financial management capacity 
of Uzbekhydroenergo and optimizing future investment programs through a master plan study. 
Institutional  and  capacity  development  for  hydropower  planning  with  increased  awareness  on 
climate  change  and  environmental  sustainability  will  be  provided  through  the  attached  TA.7 
Improved gender equality will be critical in realizing socioeconomic development. 
 
B. 
 
13. 
The  project  is  aligned  with  the  following  impact:  inclusive  economic  growth  achieved 
through  increased  clean  and  sustainable  energy  supply  (footnote  3).  The  project  will  have  the 
following outcome: clean and renewable energy generation increased.8 
 
C. 
 
Output 1: Generation capacity of small hydropower plants increased. Under output 
14. 
1, the project will design, supply, and construct HPPs with 24 MW total capacity—6 MW in Rabat

15. 
Output  2:  Climate  resilience  promoted  in  hydropower  planning.  The  project  will 
prepare a hydropower development master plan focused on climate resilience and environmental 
sustainability. Large deployment of hydropower is seen as an effective GHG mitigation strategy, 
but given the water-stressed situation of Uzbekistan, larger attention needs to be paid to the water 
resource assessment with due consideration to the climate change impacts and environmental 
sustainability  assessments.  The  attached  TA  (para.  22)  will  directly  contribute  to  output  2  by 
undertaking  critical  analytical  work  to  reassess  and  optimize  Uzbekistan’s  hydropower 
development  plan  from  climate  resilience  and  environmental  sustainability  perspectives.  The 
masterplan will also provide potential private sector investment opportunities by conducting early-
stage project studies and exploring public–private partnerships for hydropower projects. 
 
16. 
Output  3:  Uzbekhydroenergo’s  institutional  capacity  enhanced.  Output  3  will 
strengthen  Uzbekhydroenergo’s  institutional  capacity  in  financial  management  and  improve  its 
corporate  governance  to  leverage  reforms.  It  will  ensure  the  long-term  sustainability  of 
Uzbekhydroenergo, a newly formed entity, and the transparency of financial information.

The government has requested a regular loan of $60 million from ADB’s ordinary capital 
resources to help finance the project. The loan will have a 25-year term, including a grace period 
of 5 years, an annual interest rate determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered 
rate  (LIBOR)-based  lending  facility,  a  commitment  charge  of  0.15%  per  year,  and  such  other 
terms and conditions in the draft loan and project agreements. Based on the straight-line method, 
the average maturity is 15.25 years, and the maturity premium payable to ADB is 0.10% per year. 
The  government  will  relend  the  loan  proceeds  to  Uzbekhydroenergo  under  a  subsidiary  loan 
agreement.  Except  as  ADB  may  otherwise  agree,  relending  terms  will  include  (i)  commitment 
charges and interest rates identical to those applied to the loan; (ii) a repayment period, including 
a grace period, identical to that applied to the loan, and (iii) Uzbekhydroenergo bearing the foreign 
exchange and interest rate variation risks of the loan proceeds. The government has provided 
ADB  with  (i)  the  reasons  for  its  decision  to  borrow  under  ADB’s  LIBOR-based  lending  facility 
based  on  these  terms  and  conditions,  and  (ii)  an  undertaking that  these  choices  were  its  own 
decision and not made based on communication from ADB.

III. 

ATTACHED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 

 
The attached transaction TA will enhance the climate resilience of hydropower projects in 
22. 
Uzbekistan through a hydropower master plan that will optimize long-term investment considering 
climate change and environmental sustainability, and build capacity for hydropower development 
planning  (footnote  6).  The  TA  is  estimated  to  cost  $1.7  million,  of  which  $1.0  million  will  be 
financed on a grant basis by the Climate Change Fund10 and $0.5 million will be financed on a 
grant basis by the Clean Energy Fund11 under the Clean Energy Financing Partnership Facility 
and administered by ADB. Uzbekhydroenergo will provide counterpart support in the form of office 
accommodation, counterpart staff, and other in-kind contributions. ADB will oversee TA activities. 
The TA will be implemented over 15 months, with an estimated start date of September 2019. 
 

IV. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

Technical 

 
A. 
 
23. 
The project is in the Shakhrisabaz District of Kashkadarya Province in the middle course 
of the Aksu River, which is 12 km upstream of the Gissarak dam. The project site is a narrow 
valley suitable for hydropower development, and all subprojects are run-of-the-river type with no 
water  storage  capacity.  A  22  km,  35–110-kilovolt  transmission  line  will  be  built  to  export  the 
generated  electricity  to  the  nearby  substation  at  the  Gissarak  HPP.  Seismic  risk  is  sufficiently 
mitigated by the application of adequate seismic codes in the project design. Site accessibility is 
fair  as  is,  but  the  access  road  will  be  partially  expanded  and  rehabilitated for the  community’s 
improved access. 
 
24. 
The HPP outputs have been optimized to minimize environmental and social impacts. An 
environmental flow assessment helped establish technical design to deliver maximum generation 
capacity and minimum impact on sediment, optimal water flows, and the measures to integrate 
environmental sustainability and established good practices for Uzbekhydroenergo’s hydropower 
planning. The climate change assessment suggests moderate climate change risk. Many climate 
change scenarios were examined, and the reinforcement of the intake weir and floodwall for the 
powerhouse are in the project design as adaptation measures.

 Governance 

Economic and Financial 

B. 
 
25. 
An economic analysis indicates an economic internal rate of return (EIRR) of 10.9%. Given 
the  hurdle  rate  of  9.0%,  the  project  is  deemed  economically  viable.  This  considered  the  non-
incremental benefits of fuel cost savings and avoided GHG emissions, otherwise the government 
will  have  to  rely  on  thermal  power  plants  to  meet  power  demand.  Even  without  environmental 
benefits, EIRR is 10.1%. The 2.7% financial internal rate of return compares favorably with the 
1.5% weighted average cost of capital. Financial viability is gauged by comparing the revenue 
and cost streams of with- and without-project scenarios, and sensitivity analysis confirmed that 
the  project  remains  economically  and  financially  viable  against  adverse  events.  The  financial 
internal  rate  of  return  is  based  on  the  historical  trajectory  of  end-user  increases  from  2010  to 
2018. The government adopted a new tariff methodology in April 2019 that will implement gradual 
realization  of  improved  cost  recovery  level  as  part  of  financial  recovery  action  plan.  But  to  be 
conservative, these tariff scenarios were not considered in the financial analysis, which is based 
on  the  historical  tariff  level.12  In  case  of  inadequate  tariff,  the  government  assured  in  a  loan 
covenant that it will provide debt servicing and operation coverage to Uzbekhydroenergo. 
 
C. 
 
26. 
Sector governance. The government set up the Ministry of Energy on 1 February 2019 
to  regulate  the  sector.  Uzbekhydroenergo’s  revenue  stream  depends  on  payments  from  the 
transmission  company  as  the  country’s  sole  buyer  of  electricity.  The  government  has  put 
significant effort on improving the governance and strengthening the financial sustainability of the 
sector. Early achievements include the implementation of time-bound financial recovery actions 
to improve the management capacity, financial resilience, and liquidity of state-owned enterprises 
(SOEs). Among the recovery measures, the government has prioritized revenue enhancement, 
including  the  adoption  of  the  new  cost  recovery  tariff  and  improvement  of  revenue  collection 
through nationwide advanced metering projects. These measures have been covenanted under 
other ADB-funded projects. 
 
27. 
Financial  management.  Uzbekhydroenergo’s  financial  management  risk  is  high  and 
financial  management  capability  is  low.  As  a  newly  created  entity,  Uzbekhydroenergo’s 
accounting  and  financial  reporting  policies  and  procedures  follow  the  national  accounting  and 
auditing  standards  of  its  predecessors.  Supported  by  external  consultants,  Uzbekhydroenergo 
intends  to  complete  its  first  audited  statements  that  follow  International  Financial  Reporting 
Standards (IFRS) for FY2017–FY2018 by end of 2019. Uzbekhydroenergo needs to strengthen 
its institutional capacity and staff skills to consolidate its accounts under national accounting and 
auditing  standards  and  IFRS,  and  to  conduct  financial  planning  and  audit.  To  meet  IFRS 
requirements, it has prioritized (i) the implementation of first-time asset revaluation; (ii) automation 
of the accounts consideration and management reporting process; and (iii) capacity enhancement 
measures,  including  recruiting  an  adequate  number  of  qualified  accounting  staff.  Integrity  due 
diligence conducted on Uzbekhydroenergo found no significant integrity risks. 
 
28. 
Procurement. The procurement risk is moderate. Although the project is the first ADB-
funded  project  for  Uzbekhydroenergo,  it  has  sufficient  domestic  procurement  experience  and 
experience in procuring goods and services under projects funded by bilateral donors. There are 
no  limitations  in  domestic  practices  and  procedures  that  restrict  the  application  of  the  ADB

increased to full cost recovery. The government is reviewing the level of tariff increase. As of 15 August 2019, the 
government increased residential tariff by 18% and other categories of customers by 36%.

Borrowers (2017, as amended from time to time). The lack of ADB-funded project experience can 
be mitigated by engaging international project supervision consultants to aid Uzbekhydroenergo 
throughout  procurement  and  contract  execution.  ADB  will  also  provide  assistance,  including 
procurement training. 
 
29. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  government  and  Uzbekhydroenergo.  Specific  policy  requirements  and  supplementary 
measures are described in the PAM. 
 
D. 
 
Poverty and social. The major benefit of the project is the increased reliability of power 
30. 
supply  primarily  in  the  vicinity  of  the  project.  This  will  provide  stable  access  to grid-connected 
electricity,  which  will  promote  business  expansion  and  create  job  opportunities  for  local 
communities, including poor and socially disadvantaged women. In the project site, only 24.2% 
of working-age women are employed compared with 65.5% of men. As high as 46.5% of women 
neither work nor look for jobs, compared with 2.6% of men. The project will therefore contribute 
to poverty reduction around the project site, including improving the condition of the access road. 
During  construction,  the  project  is  expected  to  generate  indicatively  400  jobs  for  skilled  and 
unskilled laborers, including the poor, vulnerable groups, and women. 
 
31. 
Gender. The project is categorized effective gender mainstreaming. Gender issues and 
opportunities for gender development were considered during project preparation based on the 
due diligence on Uzbekhydroenergo and the project site. A gender action plan has been prepared 
to promote gender equality in Uzbekhydroenergo. Key features include (i) collecting, analyzing, 
monitoring,  and  reporting  sex-disaggregated  data  and  information;  and  conducting  general 
gender  awareness  training  for  Uzbekhydroenergo  employees  (at  least  50%  will  be  women), 
including  on  preventing  sexual  harassment,  exploitation,  and  abuse;  (ii)  recruiting  a  social 
development  and  gender  specialist  in  the  project  management  unit  (PMU);  (iii)  facilitating 
women’s  participation  in  project  activities;  and  (iv)  designing,  adopting,  and  implementing  a 
gender equality strategy and policy by and for Uzbekhydroenergo. 
 
E. 
 
32. 
categories are as follows.13 
 
33. 
Environment (category A). A draft environmental impact assessment (EIA) report was 
prepared  and  disclosed  in  May  2019.  Public  consultation  was  conducted  for  the  nearest 
communities  at  the  scoping  stage  and  twice  on  the  draft  EIA.  The  EIA,  which  adequately 
addressed  all  issues  raised  during  the  consultations,  identified  the  potential  impacts  that  the 
project could generate and proposed an adequate environmental management plan (EMP) with 
mitigation measures, a monitoring plan, cost estimates, and EMP implementation arrangements. 
The EMP will form part of the bidding documents. 
 
34. 
Environmental  impacts  that  could  occur  during  construction  and  operation  are  mainly 
within the sections of the Aksu River between the weir and the powerhouse that will experience 
reduced water flows, on the corridors of the transmission line and access roads, and on nearby

 villages. The main impact during operations would be on the aquatic ecology and river ecosystem 
mainly related to the presence of the weir, which is an impassable obstacle to all fish,  and the 
reduced flow, which will impact nearby villages and permanently impact the river ecosystem. As 
part of the EIA, an environmental-flow modeling was undertaken, and the study presents that the 
project  design  maintains  the  acceptable  flow  to  ensure  the  river  is  not  significantly  impacted 
(paras. 23 – 24). A carefully designed fish ladder will be included as a mitigation strategy. 
 
35. 
The Aksu River is heavily modified by the large multipurpose dam and HPPs about 12 km 
downstream from the project area, which essentially dammed the valley. Information on the river’s 
biodiversity value suggests few species of fish live in the river, and none are protected or red-
listed nationally or internationally. 14 No vulnerable species were observed during inventories of 
the area. Reduced water flow is an important concern for the local population, particularly in areas 
where piped waterway will pass, as some use river water for various purposes, including drinking. 
The water balance assessment further suggested that the river will maintain adequate water for 
people’s daily use, livestock, and irrigation. 
 
The  PMU  will  implement  the  EMP  in  compliance  with  the  Safeguard  Policy  Statement 
36. 
(2009)  and  national  environmental  regulations.  International  and  national  environmental 
consultants will strengthen the PMU’s safeguard staff capacity, while environmental specialists of 
the  project  supervision  consultant  will  help  the  PMU  implement  the  EMP.  The  engineering, 
procurement,  and  construction  contract  will  include  a  budget  for  implementing  the  mitigation 
measures. The PMU budget will include environmental consultant support, capacity building, and 
independent  monitoring  with  the  local  environmental  authority.  The  project  will  establish  a 
grievance redress mechanism to handle environmental and social safeguard issues. 
 
37. 
Involuntary resettlement (category B). The project does not envisage the acquisition of 
privately owned land, and only state-owned land will be acquired. Construction of facilities, such 
as the weir, pipelines, and the transmission line, will affect 33 households and 204 people. Of 
these, 27 households and 163 people are considered severely affected per the Safeguard Policy 
Statement  (2009).  A  resettlement  plan  disclosed  in  June  2019  has  an  entitlement  matrix  and 
resettlement budget to provide compensation at replacement cost and restore livelihoods as per 
the Safeguard Policy Statement (2009); it will be updated to an implementation-ready plan upon 
completion  of  the  detailed  design  and  engineering  by  the  engineering,  procurement,  and 
construction  contractor.  Uzbekhydroenergo  will  provide  adequate  resources  to  comply  with  all 
safeguard  requirements  in  the  resettlement  plan.  No  physical  and  economic  displacement  will 
occur  until  full  compensation  at  replacement  cost  and  all  other  entitlements  are  paid  to  the 
displaced people following the final resettlement plan.
